CHARLES BETTS, 86, died on Nov. 6, 2011, after a brief illness.Born in Monroe, La., he grew up in El Dorado, Ark. He was a veteran of the Army in the Pacific theatre in WWII. Charles graduated from Vanderbilt Medical School and trained at theMayo Clinic. He was a physician, psychiatrist and entrepreneur. Although he was recruited to UAMS, he spent most of his professional life in private practice. Through his efforts, he developed the facility that would eventually become The BridgeWay Hospital in North Little Rock, as well as the property that houses Timber Ridge Neuro-Rehabilitation Ranch in Benton. He loved his native Arkansas. Among his many interests were viniculture and astronomy. In later life, he would turn to writing genealogies and, eventually, fiction. His 61-year-marriage to Mary Nash Betts was his greatest joy. In addition to Mary, he is survived by three children: Leah Pesce, Ross Betts and Craig Betts, as well as their spouses Vince, Lynn and Claire. He is also survived by10 grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Mark's Episcopal Church at 1000 North Mississippi Avenue, Little Rock, 72207, at 10 a.m. on Saturday, Nov. 19, with a reception to follow in the parish hall. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial gifts be given to the Arkansas Hospice Foundation. Online memorial and guest book at www.griffinleggettforesthills.com.

--◊--

JANET L. (JAN) BRAWLEY, Jacksonville, born Nov. 26, 1945;on Nov. 1, 2011, went home to be with God and his son, Jesus. I am her best friend in this life and that will not end with death. Jan and I will spend eternity together - what a wonderful thingto know. I am Linda Buchheit, the best friend for the last 41 years. She had lots of patience and was strong in her walk with the Lord. There were several important things in her life: work, church, her friends and family, and spreading the love of Jesus and asking that question that all Christians should ask, and that is whether you know Jesus as your personal savior. Her job was very important to her. She worked over 30 years for Russell Yarbrough Moving Company, which became part of her family with all the drivers and her special friend, Richard Pavis, and family, and all the folks that work for Russell as well. Grace Baptist Church was her home away from home. She was active in everything and was a friend to everyone. She did the banking and the reports and anything she was asked to do for God and the church. She got so tired at the end, but she kept everything up.Survivors include brothers and their families, Doug and Shirley, of St. Louis; Leon and Polly, his friend, of St. Louis; and Burl and Jackie and family, of Montana. She had many other nieces and nephews and many other family and friends. And she was so very special to my family members. She was preceded in death by grandparents; mother and father; and other aunts and uncles; plus, her very special friend, Joey Buchheit, who went home to the Lord on Oct. 1, 2011. She will be missed so very much by many people in Arkansas and Missouri. Service was Saturday, Nov. 5, 2011, at Arkansas Funeral Care.

--◊--

INGELORE CARUTHERS, 84, of North Little Rock, passed intoeternal peace on Friday morning, Nov. 11, 2011. She was born in Butzbach, Germany, and was a member of Faith Baptist Church. She was a loving wife and mother who loved herfamily fiercely. She met the love of her life, John Bruce Caruthers, in Germany. She left her family behind and came to the United States in 1955. She is survived by her sweetheart, “Johnnie;” her two daughters, Elka Lang (Chris), Barbara Russ (Gary); three granddaughters, Jennifer Fithen (Dan), Ashley Russ, Lindsey Russ, and grandson, Jonathan Ledrick; two greatgrandsons, Jacob Sierra and Caleb Fithen; sisters, Gudrum McClure, of Goodland, Kan., and Mariechen Rinn, of Germany. She also leaves to cherish her memory extended family and friends who will miss her dearly.Visitation will be held from 10 a.m. to 11 a.m. at Griffin Leggett Rest Hills Funeral Home on Monday, Nov. 14, 2011, with funeral service to follow at 11 a.m. in the Rest Hills Chapel. Entombment will be at Griffin Leggett Rest Hills Memorial Park. Please visit the online registry at www.griffinleggettresthills.com.

She was preceded in death by parents, Jennie Bell Collins and Victor Simpson; husband, James Charleston; son, Ezell Laws; brother, R.B. Simpson; sisters, Gussie Dawson and Mavis Ellington; grandsons, Keith Charleston and Sean Johnson. She leaves to mourn and cherish her memories: children, Gloria Dean Charleston, Linda F. Laws, Janet (Walter) Mason, Brenda Gilbert, Michael Laws, all of Little Rock, Ark., and Rose (Jervy) Davis, of Columbia, S.C. Vernell was devoted to her 17 grandchildren, 31 great-grandchildren, and one great-great-grandchild; siblings: James Simpson, Kansas City, Mo., Thyria Riggle, Milwaukee, Wis., Louvetria Walton, Vallejo, Calif., Mattie Davis, Dumas, Ark., Charlie Mae Simpson, Little Rock, Ark., and Vernice Deshazier, Hanford, Calif.; and a host of nieces, nephews and friends. The homegoing services will be held on Wednesday, Nov. 16, 2011, 11 a.m. Interment will follow at Rest In Peace Memorial Garden, Hensley, Ark. Viewing: Tuesday,3 - 5 p.m., both services at Ruffin and Jarrett Funeral Home, 1200 South Chester Street, Little Rock, Ark. (501) 372-1305.

Marjorie is survived by her sons: Jeff Fournier of Dallas, Texas; Michael Fournier of Little Rock; and Jerry Fournier and wife, Patricia, of Roland, Ark.; three grandchildren, Karman Hunt, of Russellville, Tonya McDaniel, of Maumelle, and Justin Fournier, of Conway;six great-grandchildren, Hannah Hunt, Reese Hunt, Demi McDaniel, Dale McDaniel, Dax McDaniel and Bailey Ann Fournier; and a brother, Bill Jones, of Little Rock. Burial will follow at Pinecrest Memorial Park in Alexander. Online guestbook: www.rollerfuneralhomes.com/chenal.

LORENE E. (TWYFORD) HENDRIXSON, 88, of Ferndale passedaway Thursday, Nov. 10, 2011. She was born June 25, 1923, in Judsonia, Ark., to Herbert and Edith Twyford. In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her husband of 57years, L.D. Hendrixson, and two sisters, Helen Dale and Joyce Hubach. Lorene is survived by two sons: Jim Hendrixson and wife, Joann, of Hot Springs, Mike Hendrixson and wife, Kathy, of Ferndale; daughter, Karen Elrod and husband, Jim, of Ferndale. Other survivors include eight grandchildren: Michael, Mark, Steve and David Hendrixson, Kevin and Cody Elrod, Michelle Goldman and Carla Turpin; 12 great-grandchildren, as well as her sister Gearldine McIntire. Lorene was a seamstress for Ottenheimer brothers for many years. When L.D. retired from the Little Rock Fire Dept. in 1974, they moved to Ferndale to enjoy country living, gardening and grandkids. She was the heart of our family and was there for all of us, no matter what. We will always miss her, and we are thankful for all the good times and laughs that she gave us. Funeral services will be held at 2 p.m. on Monday, Nov. 14, 2011, at Griffin Leggett Rest Hills Funeral Home Chapel, 7724Landers Road, North Little Rock, Ark., 72117, (501) 835-3515, with Allan Greer of Parkway Place Baptist Church officiating. Burial will follow at Rest Hills Memorial Park. Visitation will be held from 12:30 ‚Äì 2 p.m., on Monday, prior to funeral services. The family wishes to express heartfelt thanks to the staff of Sherwood Nursing and Rehab for the kindness and care shown to our mother. Special thanks to Debbie and Barb whom she loved dearly. In lieu of flowers memorials may be made to the Susan G. Komen Foundation. To sign Lorene’s online tribute please visit www.griffinleggettresthills.com.

REV. GEORGE G. ROWELL, 74, departed to the land of his heavenly reward on Nov. 10, 2011. He was born Aug. 18, 1937, to the late Carl Sr. and Dovey Rowell. Rev. G. Rowell loved preaching, singing, and ministering to people. He had a great sense ofhumor. Everyone who knew him loved him. He will be missed by all. He was a high school graduate of Westlake High in Westlake, La., and a college graduate of Apostolic Bible Institute in St. Paul, Minn. He pastored a total of five churches throughout his life and brought many people to the Lord. He pastored churches in Kansas and Louisiana and his last pastorate was at Marigold Pentecostal Church in Little Rock. He is preceded in death by his parents; his daughter, Tamara Lynn Rowell; and grandson, Chaddrick Shane Harris. He is survived by his loving wife, Neoma Rowell; his brother and sister-in-law, Carl Jr. and Delores Rowell; his sister and brother-in-law, Lois (Bill) and Rev. Maurice James; daughter and son-in-law, Trecia Rowell Francois and Danny Francois; granddaughters, Courtney Francois, and Danielle Bratton and her husband Danny Bratton; great-granddaughter, Chloe Bratton; and many friends and church family that loved him andwill miss him dearly. Visitation will be held on Sunday, Nov. 13, 2011, from 2-4 p.m., at Dial and Dudley Funeral Home in Bryant. A celebration of Rev. Rowell’s life will be held on Monday, Nov. 14, 2011, at 1 p.m., at Christian Life Center, 12923 West Markham, Little Rock. To sign online guest book visit www.dialanddudleyfuneralhome.com.

LEONARD SAUL SPITZER, age 94, died Nov. 11, 2011, in LittleRock, Ark. Len was born in Chicago, Ill., to Sam and Anna Spitzer, and raised in Oak Park, Ill., with his brother, Jerry. In their childhood, summers were always spent at their summerhome in Glenn, Mich., a past that held many fond memories.

During his childhood, Len became well known as a golf champion, winning the Chicago City Title at the age of 16. Following graduation from Oak Park High School, he went to college at the University of Texas, where he was the Captain of the Golf team and was the Southwest Conference Golf Champion. Following college, he married Sidney Stifft, of Little Rock. Although Sidney died at a very young age, he always remembered her as the “nicest person he ever knew.” During World War II, Lt. Spitzer was a bombardier in the Fifth Air Force, flying 35 combat missions over Europe with missions deep into Germany and Romania. He was particularly proud of his war service and those he flew with.Upon returning from his wartime service, he lived in Chicago for a brief period until he moved to Little Rock in 1949. Soon thereafter, he began teaching at Pulaski Heights Junior High and became principal. For the next few years, he was principal at Forest Heights Junior High, Hall High School, and Parkview High School, which he opened and ran for several years until his retirement. During his life, golf had always been his primary interest, with many championships to his record. He is survived by his son, Len Spitzer Jr. and his wife, Katy, of Oakland, Calif.; his daughter, Sidney Spitzer, of Little Rock; his grandchildren, Jill Ward, Robyn Hennessey, Jerry Coelho, and Nick Coelho; and one greatgrandson, Ronan Ward. He was preceded in death by his wife, Sidney Spitzer; his second wife, Juanita Wheeler; and a son, Sam Spitzer; and step-son, Chris Spitzer. There will be a graveside service at Oakland Jewish Cemetery for immediate family.A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Hospice Home Care, 2200 South Bowman Rd., Little Rock, Ark., 72211. Arrangements by Little Rock Funeral Home, 8801 Knoedl Ct., Little Rock, 501-224-2200. Mr. Spitzer’s online guestbook may be signed at www.littlerockfuneralhome.com.

ALEXANDER - Lois Marie Lawson Havniear, 72, of Alexander,passed away Thursday, Nov. 10, 2011. She worked in the lumber industry as an account clerk and also worked in retail sales. She loved professional baseball especially the St.Louis Cardinals. She is survived by her daughter, Diana L. Henry, of Alexander; three sons, Roger W. (Lisa) Havniear, of Mabelvale, Ronald W. (Christy) Havniear, of Traskwood, and Richard W. (Kimberly) Havniear, of Jacksonville; two brothers, Bobbie J. Lawson, of Jacksonville, and J. Emmett Lawson, of Alexander; sister, Connie L. Havniear Sr., and sister, Ruby C. Kret. Funeral services will be held 2 p.m., Monday, in the North Little Rock Funeral Home Chapel. Burial will be in Pinecrest Memorial Park. BENTON - J D Caldwell, 91, of Benton, passed away Friday, Nov. 11, 2011, at Saline Memorial Hospice House in Bryant. He was born on Nov. 3, 1920, in Lonsdale, Ark., to the late Walter and Dora Caldwell. He was also preceded in death by two brothers, Fletcher and Toy Caldwell; one sister, Harriet Harris; and one grandson, Roy Dee Pruitt. Mr. Caldwell was a member of First Baptist Church of Benton and served as an usher for many years. He was also a WWII veteran who served under General Patton in Europe.He was awarded six medals; a Purple Heart; four Battle Stars; and a Bronze Star. He retired from Southwestern Bell Telephone in 1983, after 37 years of service. He is survived by his wife, Audrey Caldwell; three daughters, Janis Pruitt and husband Elton, Delaine Baughtman and husband Frank, and Belinda Simmons and husband Rick; one brother, Walter “Pinky” Caldwell; seven grandchildren, Angela Pruitt, Tammy Palmer, Elton Mark Pruitt, Doug Baughtman, Erin Baughtman, Trey Baughtman, and Callie Simmons; and seven great-grandchildren. Funeral service will be held at 2 p.m., Monday, Nov. 14, 2011, in the chapel of Roller-Ballard Funeral Home, 315-4047, with Dr.Rick Grant officiating. Interment will follow in Forest Hills Memorial Park in Alexander. Visitation will be held from 4 to 6 p.m., Sunday afternoon, Nov. 13, at the funeral home. Memorials may be made to Saline Memorial Hospice House, 23157 I-30, Bryant, Ark., 72022, or First Baptist Church, 211 S. Market, Benton, Ark., 72015. Online guestbook www.rollerfuneralhomes.com/ ballard.

GLENDALE - Annie Pearl Hoover Taylor, 88, of Glendale, died Friday, Nov. 11, 2011, at Jefferson Regional Medical Center in Pine Bluff, after a brief illness. Mrs. Taylor was born Feb. 26, 1923, in Glendale, Ark., to W. V. and Eva Wilson Hoover. She was raised in Glendale and graduated from Glendale High School. She attended Arkansas A&M at Monticello and later received her Bachelor’s of Education from Arkansas State Teachers College in Conway. Annie Hoover married Norris Reed ‘Mickey’ Taylor on Dec. 18, 1943, in Bossier City, La. Mrs. Taylor was an elementary school teacher and taught in several different school systems, including Watson Chapel, Grapevine, Searcy, and Star City before retiring in 1983. She was a member of Mt. Olivet United Methodist Church.
